text:
Ours is also a 'Song of Ice and Fire'.. the relatively stable period in our climate
 over the past 10 000 years isn't going to go on forever.  Regardless of
 human inputs, the climate is always shifting toward periods of 
glaciation or, more rarely, shifting toward hot-house conditions.  
Neither of these states is viable for civilisation as we know it.  So we
 can either somehow extend the pristine Holocene-like conditions 
indefinitely with massive geoengineering, OR we can do everything we can
 to eliminate our footprint and become a civilisation that adapts to a 
world that will periodically see much of the northern hemisphere covered
 in really thick ice sheets.  Is artificially maintaining the Holocene 
even viable for the long-term thrivability of life on Earth?  Is a 
super-adaptive and slimmed down civilisation that is able to withstand 
ice-ages even remotely possible?  Neither of these scenarios seem 
possible to me.
author: Kurt Coleman

text:
People in the comments are completely missing the point. I know Vox likes to spread climate change propaganda but this "theory" is not only about climate change and it's not really just a "theory". Everyone knows that one of the main premises for the series is that people are ignoring real threats while fighting for political control, this "threat" can be climate change, werewolves or some faraway meteor. It doesn't even matter what GRRMs inspiration for this was, you can interpret it in any way you want because it's a simple truth about utilitarian human nature. 

On the other hand, the world of ice and fire is very complex and contains lots of "secret" meanings. Even minor things, like religion, are very well thought out. How every religion (the old gods, the lord of light, the many-faced god) give their believers/priests magical powers while the most common religion doesn't, the Faith of the Seven.  How dragons are a metaphor for nuclear weapons. Not to mention how gray and well written all the characters are, they reach moral ambiguity like no other work in the fantasy genre.

text:
Absolutely not. Another garbage attempt to create the next big fan theory in ASOIAF by someone whose knowledge is clearly show-specific. The most amusing part of all these great "theories" is that they all compare themselves to R+L=J, and then project themselves as the next big one on the horizon.

The climate on the planet that ASOIAF takes place on is controlled by MAGIC, not the rotation around the primary star vis-a-vis the rotation on its own axis. The Long Night was a 100-year old winter, caused by the invasion of the Others, and it ended with the their defeat.

The two deities, R'hllor and The Great Other, are constantly in conflict with each other, competing to consume humanity for magical power and dominance over the planet. The planet's seasons reflect the current state of this conflict. Long summers result when R'hllor or those associated with fire in some way, or those who stand opposed to The Great Other, are in dominance over the planet. When The Great Other is dominant, or when R'hllor is significantly weakened, long winters are observed. 

ASOIAF is not about climate change; it is about how the advent of humans into the planet is slowly destroying the influence of magic. Beginning from the First Men (and then the Andals) destroying weirwoods to curb the influence of the children's magic to the Order of Maesters systematically eliminating magic from the world, humanity's rise has suppressed the power of the primal forces that ruled the planet. The Children of the Forest, the Giants, the Others, the race that built the foundation of the Hightower; all these races and their magic have been negatively impacted by the rise of humanity. The current invasion of the Others is likely something of a final stand.

MAGIC vs MIGHT. That is the essence of ASOIAF.

text:
A. This isn't really a theory of the same kind as R+L=J. This is about how to interpret ASOIAF thematically, not about the literal climate forces active within Westeros. Jon Snow's parentage obviously has no bearing upon the real world and GRRM hinted so obviously at the theory that I hesitate to even label it as such. 
B. The video is absolutely right in that a huge point of the books and the show is that the people of Westeros are so preoccupied with their petty squabbles that they ignore the existential threat to humanity.  Climate change certainly fits this template but the books don't necessarily single out climate change.
C. Yes, Preston Jacobs more often than not spews out nonsensical and far-fetched bs, but seeing as he loathes the show and constantly uses the books to undermine D&D's logic I don't see how his knowledge base can be show-specific.
D. As far as your magic vs. might statement, that seems very reasonable. However, magic clearly does not exist in the real world and, if we're going to look for any meaning or any reality-applicable political/ethical statements, we would at least have to consider the symbolism that this presents. Likewise, if we view this as an allegory for man's suppression and destruction of nature, we get a picture that actually does support the climate change theory.

text:
Solving climate change will require the world's largest and most powerful countries like China, India and the United States to make some sacrifices in the short-term and put aside their political competition with each other.  

We're fucked unless fossil fuels get replaced as the world's energy source.  Renewables like solar and wind are just not going to be able to cut it to power the world's economy, they're too unreliable and unproductive and will require a lot of storage to cover the many times when the sun will not shine and the wind will not blow.  

I think that generation 4 nuclear is the solution, it's not like shitty generation 1 nuclear with reactors like Fukushima and Chernobyl that melt down and use less than 1% of the energy in their fuel.  Fuel from the rare and expensive isotope of uranium U-235.  

Some can even run on the abundant supply of 'spent fuel' rods that are just lying around all over the world and no one really knows what to do with them.  Others are breeder reactors that can run on the much more abundant isotope U-238.  Molten salt reactors are unable to melt down due to their radically different design from conventional nuclear.  If thorium can be used as fuel then there would be a very abundant supply of energy since its most common isotope is good for fuel and is about as abundant as lead in the earth.  

If the problems getting in the way of making real nuclear fusion power plants get solved then the world's energy problems will be solved permanently.

text: An unseen issue that seems like a myth and is not taken seriously yet leads to the climax is a common scenario in entertainment stories. Politics just use the already brain washed scenario in it's favor. It is also not completely brain washing but human instinct to disbelieve something that cannot be seen even though evidence presents its self. It's common for the evidence to be rationalized as something else. That is because there are times when something seems to be one thing and turns out to be something completely different. But there are differences between the two scenarios witch need detailed observation to tell the difference. Usually the majority is not capable of the detailed observation and thus majority rules and the situation is brushed away as a less sinister issue. This is also why you have the scenario in entertainment where there is the one smart guy trying to convince the majority about something until it is too late but the smart guy comes up with a plan after realizing the majority wont listen and saves the day. I've literally have seen people have contradictory opinions about two similar situations based off what they had watched on tv before hand on countless occasions(be observational and you see a lot). I used to think my lack of interaction was because I was too busy observing, but in reality it's just really weird to interact with people because you start to see that they do weird and fucked up shit but you must continue to interact like you didn't realize it because the group as a whole wont understand you reactions because they don't see it them selves. text:
George R.R. Martin takes inspiration from real historical events when writing the books. The coming of winter and the migration of the free folk, who are being perused by an unstoppable supernatural army, has clear similarities with the events leading up to the fall of the Western Roman Empire.
Winters grew longer, "the sun gave forth its light without brightness", crops failed and there was famine. Then the Huns came, seen as a supernatural punishment from god, appearing to be unstoppable. The Germanic tribes (Goths, Vandals etc.) forced their way south to escape the inhospitable climate and the advancing Huns. While this was happening generals and powerful families squabbled over power within the Western Roman Empire, weakening it from the inside though civil wars.

At the end of Game of Thrones there probably wont be a throne left to fight over.

Possible things you can do about global warming:
1. Sign up for the Night's Watch - devote your life to combating global warming through research or gainful employment, probably taking a hit in terms of lifelong salary in the process.
2. Send troops to the Night's Watch - donate to clean energy projects, and divest your assets from fossil fuel industries.
3. Convince your liege lord - write to your representative and share information about global warming.
4. Do whatever you can - live in a way which is not energy intensive.

It is easy to feel powerless and let that lead to apathy, but that is a response that has been manufactured in part by global warming denialists and their backers. In more enlightened parts of the world than those that speak English, ordinary people are doing their part to save the planet. Time we put aside our feelings and stepped up too. ¬†@stuckupcurlyguy¬† While that may be true in the US, it's not true in other countries. And with all the government funding your glorious solar panels are shit. Yeah, they have their merit for one or two family housing, but for anything else? Forget it.

Germany built over 40,000 MW in solar. On good days, when the weather is perfect, they barely scrape in 50% of that theoretical production. And guess what, most of the time the weather in Germany isn't good enough for even that. Now engineers in Germany call "renewable" energy "New Unstable Energy" and "spasming power", because, guess what, it's too inefficient and unreliable for any proper real world application like industry.

author: Tom

text:
¬†@stuckupcurlyguy¬† Most of what are called "subsidies" are simply tax allowances for business expenses, such as taxes paid to foreign governments. These are not specific to oil companies but apply to other companies doing business in foreign countries. They call these subsidies because it would mean extra tax revenue if they denied these business allowances.

The subsidies per kw-hour for fossil fuels are tiny compared to the subsidies per kw-hour for green energy.

If fossil fuel companies are forced to pay higher taxes than other businesses, these extra costs will just be passed on to consumers in the form of higher energy prices. The same is true of carbon taxes.
author: George Applegate

text:
¬†@*****¬†
"make greener sources of energy more economically viable" You assume that it is possible to make green energy cheap enough to compete with fossil fuels. There's no reason to believe this will ever be possible. When energy is more expensive, it means more people are being paid to produce that energy - that is where the money goes.

A common economic fallacy is that jobs are always good, regardless of what the worker produces. The wealth of a nation is not truly measured by dollars changing hands, but by what useful goods are produced and thus consumed per capita. Work spent in unproductive activities, such as when more people are required to produce the same energy, impoverishes the nation.

text:
¬†@TomHasVideo¬† Are you making a distinction between tide gauge data and scientific data?" Tide gauge data is how sea level is measured long-term. Or are you simply making the distinction between "data that contradicts my beliefs" and "scientific data?" 

A common technique amongst AGW propagandists is to label data that contradicts AGW as "denial," and thus invalid. This very handily insulates them from new information. 

Another technique is to select one from among the 10,000+ climate science papers because it happens to support an alarmist claim, and then assert that it represents the view of all climate scientists. This is how the myth of accelerating sea level rise is propagated.
author: George Applegate

text:
¬†@*****¬†
You argue from the perspective of a believer who wants to explain away contradictory information.

No one disputes the greenhouse effect, but the assertion of the IPCC is that positive feedbacks (which are rare in nature) will somehow triple the greenhouse effect of CO2. Skeptics question this assertion, especially given that temperatures have not risen as models predicted, and point to negative feedbacks that may well attenuate rather than amplify the effect of CO2. Keep in mind that only a fraction of the greenhouse effect on Earth is attributable to CO2, and CO2 is already absorbing 87% (according to the IPCC) of what it theoretically can.

The IPCC offers plausibility arguments for how greatly increasing CO2 could drive temperatures ever higher, but these are far from proven, and are not widely accepted by the climate science community. The stated purpose of the IPCC is to report on man-made climate change, so I'm skeptical they would eagerly report the opposite - i.e. that the IPCC was not necessary.

I agree that the climate is very difficult to model and thus to predict. It is not at all surprising that the models were unable to predict the 18 year hiatus given the complexity of the climate. It therefore follows that the model predictions for climate in 2100 cannot be relied on.

The IPCC and other climate alarmists have been indoctrinating the public with expectations of climate doom for decades now, while evidence for such claims diminishes by the day. I guess it is not surprising that news that climate doom isn't happening is greeted with anger rather than relief. People become very attached to their beliefs, and entire generations have heard nothing else.
author: George Applegate

text:
